question: What are TAMs in cancer therapy?
ideal_answer: TAMs are Tumor Associated Macrophages and are important in Cancer therapy.

Tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) is a promising therapeutic target for cancer immunotherapy, while TAMs targeting therapy using nano-sized drug delivery system (NDDS) is a great challenge.
Tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) play a crucial part in cancer evolution.
Tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) of M2 phenotype have mediated the immunosuppression in a tumor microenvironment, facilitating the escape of tumor cells from immunosurveillance.
In this review, we outline the importance of tumor-associated macrophages (TAM), a major component of the TME, in the response of tumors to cancer therapy.
In particular, tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) are the most abundant leucocyte subset in many cancers and play a major role in the creation of a protective niche for tumor cells.
These cells, known as tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs), play complex but pivotal roles in the outcome of photodynamic therapy (PDT) of malignant lesions.
Tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) represent the most abundant innate immune cells in tumors.
Tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) are among the most abundant immune cells in the TME.
